title: 114_hr4698
content:
The Act titled "Securing Aviation from Foreign Entry Points and Guarding Airports Through Enhanced Security Act of 2016" focuses on assessing security at last point of departure airports. The Act "Securing Aviation from Foreign Entry Points and Guarding Airports Through Enhanced Security Act of 2016" mandates a security risk assessment of last point of departure airports with nonstop flights to the United States within 180 days. The assessment includes evaluating coordination with foreign governments, intelligence capabilities, terrorist transit, and passenger screening practices. The security assessment of last point of departure airports with nonstop flights to the United States includes evaluating passenger security screening practices, security vetting of aviation workers, access controls, and government mandates on passenger name record collection. SEC. 3. SECURITY COORDINATION ENHANCEMENT PLAN. The Administrator of the Transportation Security Administration must submit a plan to Congress and the Government Accountability Office within 240 days of this Act's enactment. The plan aims to improve security collaboration for international-inbound aviation by enhancing coordination and information sharing with various partners. This includes assessing security capabilities at high-risk foreign airports. The Transportation Security Administration must submit a plan to Congress and the Government Accountability Office within 240 days to enhance security at foreign airports. The Comptroller General of the United States will review the effectiveness of these efforts in securing international-inbound aviation within 180 days. SEC. 4. WORKFORCE ASSESSMENT.

Within 270 days of this Act's enactment, the Transportation Security Administration Administrator must provide Congress with a comprehensive assessment of all personnel involved in global transportation security efforts, ensuring assignments are risk-based and intelligence-driven.

SEC. 5. DONATION OF SCREENING EQUIPMENT TO PROTECT THE UNITED STATES. The Transportation Security Administration can donate security screening equipment to foreign airports to address specific vulnerabilities to US security. A detailed explanation must be provided to Congress before any donation is made. The Transportation Security Administration can donate security screening equipment to foreign airports to address vulnerabilities. Congress must be provided with details including the reason for the donation, evacuation plan for emergencies, maintenance plan, and total value of the donation. The National Cargo Security Program is established under Section 6. The Administrator of the Transportation Security Administration may evaluate foreign countries' air cargo security programs to determine if they meet US security standards. If a foreign country's program is deemed equivalent, it will be approved and recognized by the Administrator. The Transportation Security Administration approves foreign countries' air cargo security programs if they meet US standards. If a program no longer meets these standards, approval may be revoked or suspended. The Administrator may revoke or suspend a foreign country's air cargo security program if it does not meet US standards. Notification must be given to relevant committees within 30 days of such action. SEC. 7. CHECKPOINTS OF THE FUTURE. The Aviation Security Advisory Committee is tasked with developing recommendations for more efficient passenger screening processes, considering factors like checkpoint configuration, technology innovation, addressing vulnerabilities, preventing security breaches, best practices in aviation security, and input from airport and aircraft operators. The Aviation Security Advisory Committee will submit a report to Congress on recommendations for improving screening processes within one year of the Act's enactment. The House of Representatives passed the bill on April 26, 2016. Karen L. Haas is the Clerk.
